post.body: This is a post on my new hub. ~~None of you should be able to see this yet (hopefully).~~

Alright, so everything seems to be in order for my new awesome hub and cleanly migrating hubs for those of you who want to switch to my hub, or the infinity one (or even Red->Blue/Blue->Red for you color traitors).

First things first is to seed the new hub you want to switch to. You're likely already seeding Red and Blue, but you'll need to seed the [Kaffie hub](/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv) or the infinity hub, if you want to switch to those. If you're seeing this post, you should already have the Kaffie hub.

Don't bother going to the 'create profile' page. That's for suckers. It's nice to check which subs you're seeding, but the 'create profile' button just messes things up. Instead, go to your home sub (you can figure out what this is by hovering over your name and looking at the URL) and go into the /data/users/[your id]/ folder. You'll want to copy over this whole folder into the new hub's equivalent.

In the destination hub, open up content.json in a text editor (like sublime, so formatting doesn't get messed up). All you want to do is edit 'address' to point to the new hub, instead of your old one.

Next, open up data.json in the destination hub. You'll see all your original hub data. Here's what we're going to do. Delete all of the entries under 'comments'. These are comments relating to the hub they're in, so you don't need them migrated. You should still keep the array though, since that's where all your new hub comments will go.

Change the 'hub' to the new hub you're migrating to. Just like you did in the content.json. This is a reference to say what your 'home hub' is. We'll eventually edit this in EVERY hub you're seeding or posted in, but one step at a time.

Change 'next_comment_id' to 1. Since we deleted the comments, we need to reset the counter.

Here's where you get a choice. There's two options for your posts. Either you can migrate the data, which switches the name link on those posts (and hosts it in the new hub) but also unlink everyone's comments, or you can leave the posts in the old hub, and start fresh. If you start fresh, your old posts will still appear, but they'll link back to your old hub profile. So keep that in mind. I personally started fresh.

To start fresh, do the same thing to your posts as you did your comments. Delete all the entries and change the 'next_post_id' to 1.

Lastly, delete everything under 'post_like'. Keep the array though.

That should set up your new hub account. Now we need to repoint your data on the other hubs. For each hub you've posted in, go into that hub's folder and find your user folder, like we did before.

On each one, open the data.json and simply edit the 'hub' variable to point to your home hub. This is probably optional (as it repoints the comment links), but I went ahead and did it to reduce the amount of problems.

On your original sub, a couple more things need to be tweaked. Delete everything under 'follows'. Remove the variable entirely. Delete 'next_follow_id' as well. Change 'hub' to your new hub, as usual. And if you opted to migrate your posts, delete the entire 'posts' section along with the 'next_post_id' variable. If not, leave it. I didn't migrate, so I left the posts there.

Change the intro to something to notify people to switch the profile they follow. This is technically optional, and you can just delete it if you feel like it. Delete the 'avatar' if you migrated posts (it's unneeded), but if you kept your posts there, then you'll want to keep it, as otherwise your old posts won't have an avatar (perhaps this is preferred?)

Finally, we save up and go to sign/publish our changes. Visit each hub site (the actual site down at the bottom of zerohello, not zerome). Then drag the sidebar open and select 'i own this site'. Put your user content.json in the bottom box (should look something like: data/users/[yourid]/content.json) and hit sign. It'll prompt for a privatekey. Use your ZeroID private key (found at the top of your zeronet's user.json file) and then click publish. Do this for every hub you've edited.

---

So now all of the changes are made and published. Everyone else should see everything just fine. But you might still be stuck logged into your old hub. So delete every hub but your destination hub. Then go into zerome and ensure you're logged in properly. Finally, redownload each hub and everything should be good to go!

Update on the login issue for KaffieID. The login code detects your cert name, which is the little `name@zeroid.bit` and then compares it to the one in your `content.json` file. If they match, it sets that as your user. If not, then it doesn't. So username switching systems, or people with matching names/providers (such as nanasi/kaffie that don't guarantee name uniqueness) you get login issues. And switching an id (even with the same auth keys and such) makes a login issue, despite signing working correctly anyway.

Apparently the only think you need to change is the content.json in your home hub, to fix this. just change `"cert_user_id": "name@provider.bit",` to whatever it is that is in the top right (your cert name). If this field is missing, there'll be issues. And if it doesn't match, there'll be issues.

The fix I posted below (changing the detection in all.js) to be based on auth_address) works as well, and lets you log in regardless (so if your signing is good, you're all set). Though amusingly, the little `name@provider.bit` that appears everywhere *is* based on that field in the content.json. Interesting...

I'd still like the change to all.js to be made though, so that this issue doesn't occur. Having broken logins is never good.

So there's been signing/publishing issues issues with KaffieID and I seem to have found out why. When there's a cert_sign in the content.json, ZeroNet attempts to create a new cert to recreate the cert_sign to verify.

Here's the relevant code:

```
def verifyCert(self, inner_path, content):
        from Crypt import CryptBitcoin

        rules = self.getRules(inner_path, content)
        if not rules.get("cert_signers"):
            return True  # Does not need cert

        name, domain = content["cert_user_id"].split("@")
        cert_address = rules["cert_signers"].get(domain)
        if not cert_address:  # Cert signer not allowed
            self.log.error("Invalid cert signer: %s" % domain)
            return False
        return CryptBitcoin.verify(
            "%s#%s/%s" % (rules["user_address"], content["cert_auth_type"], name), cert_address, content["cert_sign"]
)
```

This means that only certs that have signed using `useraddress#authtype/name` are valid. Which eliminates the ability to change names but keep the same cert. This verification requiring the name is entirely useless, and you can get around the entire issue by modifying the content.json to simply not have a cert_sign.

So... what should we do? Just force everyone to use the `useraddress#authtype/name` and hope that no one pushes out a cert that uses something different? KaffieID uses `useraddress#authtype/kaffie.bit` so that names can freely change. However, that seems to mess up the python verification. The cert works, it's just unexpected due to not using the name. Should I just change KaffieID to mess up certs when you change names? Seems kind of dumb that changing a name for an ID service would mess up your cert. I mean, we already have public/private keys. Is a specialized cert_sign in a particular format that breaks if you change names necessary?

Alternatively we can look a bit further on what's actually going on behind the scenes, and perhaps fix it entirely? Perhaps certs should have a 'format' for the verification to take place?

@nofish: I'm interested to see what you have to say. At the moment the cert_sign appears to me as a redundant check that breaks certs that use different formatting. Why not simply change the check to `useraddress#authtype/signersite`? Is there even a way to change this now that people have been using ZeroIDs? Would the 'format' option I described work?

```
Internal error: TypeError: 'unicode' object does not support item assignment
UiWebsocket.py line 98 > UiWebsocket.py line 177 > SidebarPlugin.py line 602 > SiteStorage.py line 121 > Db.py line 316
```

Well that's a shame. Apparently my past 2-3 posts weren't visible by anyone using the new client, due to a typo in my content.json. I was completely unaware of the problem, as it signed/published just fine due to the presence of older clients accepting it (like the kindlyfire proxy).

If you messed with your content.json, now might be a good time to check it, to be sure it's in proper working order. For my issue, I had `auth_type` instead of `cert_auth_type`.

I wanted to share [this Kaffiene search](http://127.0.0.1:43110/kaffiene.bit/?q=15GAu5QYg34TLzD4b2WMpZSid9S2K6M54h&i=ZeroName) because I was shocked that Erkan had registered nearly 25% of all ZeroNet domain names.

However, I realized that Kaffiene's share links didn't specify an index, which means the search would've pointed back to the Kaffiene Index and the point would've been lost. So I did a Kaffiene update to include the index in the share link, so that searches may be properly shared.

Though, that makes me think: Page number isn't share either. I was told by friends/family that there's no need to share the page, but I keep thinking otherwise. Should I include it anyway? It would make it easy to keep searches going over longer periods of time, or to continue a search that you stopped looking through.

I really want [ZeroTube](/1FUQPLXHimgCvYHH7v3bJXspJ7bMBUXcEb) to be a success, but no one cares to seed anything... The big issue seems to be that there's no way to get the magnet link/torrent file from a video, meaning you can only ever seed it when you're on the page. And uploading is really glitchy, so if you use the direct thing, you're shit outta luck.

I went ahead and mirrored some videos (Cosmos Laundromat, Fastcast vids, etc) as well as uploaded a new one of my own (Deadpool movie). For those who want to just manually upload stuff, here's my process:

1. Drag/drop the movie into webtorrent. This is to start the seeding process. Don't include anything besides the mp4. Webms don't work, and I'm guessing stuff like AVIs don't work either.

2. Right click on the newly seeded torrent and hit 'copy magnet link'. You'll paste this in the 'magnet' field on your data.json.

3. Add a new video in your data.json. Here's the format:

```
{
"video_id": "",
"title": "",
"description": "",
"magnet": "",
"date_added": ""
}
```

For 'video_id', it's expecting the bittorrent hash listed under 'bith'. It's in the magnet link near the beginning. For date_added, my new entries have the format `2016-08-29T02:12:14.588Z`. (Edit: You can use [this site](http://www.unixtimestamp.com/) to generate a timestamp. Use the 'ISO 8601' one.)

Have fun. Still no way to increase the seeds besides manually sharing the magnet link and downloading through webtorrent (or staying on the page). You can grab a video's magnet link in the same manner. Alternatively you can grab the bith from the end of the watching URL, and paste that right into webtorrent desktop.

And remember, the more support ZeroTube gets, the more webtorrents are seeded for *any* webtorrent video service. So let's work together to kickstart a solid video streaming platform for ZeroNet :D

Edit: Help mirror youtube videos by pasting the url into this site http://keepvid.com/ and then hitting the 'Download MP4 - 720p' option.
Uploaded a quick walkthrough on how I upload videos to ZeroTube. Hopefully it helps out people who were confused about how to do it.

comment.body: So hopefully everything worked out correctly. Please confirm. All my posts should be visible on a new  '12h' address. The profile link on this post should like to the '12h' address, but the older posts should link back to my red page. Comments everywhere should link to '12h'. Please unfollow my red page and follow my new Kaffie Hub page, if everything's going well. Thanks :)
Yea, someone made a ridiculously long name. That's not me :P. But are the links all working? And the content merging correctly?
Update: You may also have to edit and sign the content.json located in the 1UDbADib99KE9d3qZ87NqJF2QLTHmMkoV site in order to change your hub in the 'all users' listing.
It's definitely up. Check the proxy: https://proxy1.zn.kindlyfire.me/kaffiene.bit

@Bot: On the 'post on my hub', that's because you clicked 'join hub' without migrating your user data. So you have two profiles. One of which is on my hub. Namely we need a way to easily manage the 'hub' variable, as well as use that solely for identifying which hub you're on. At the moment, it doesn't seem to work like that, and causes problems.

Cross-hub posting works fine, the comments are placed in the hub you're commenting in like they should. If your comments on my hub were placed in a different hub, I wouldn't be able to see them.

In reality, what we need is a profile page being determined solely by the 'hub' variable, and the posts to be fetched from a 'posted hubs' list (like a new variable listing the hubs you've posted in. This list would be fetched from the home hub.). I think that'd solve all the problems.

Edit: As it is now, the URL defines which hub to load for your profile. That's a huge mistake, as going to the wrong hub would cause problems.

@P2P: Actually, likes are properly sorted by their hub, and correctly refer to the post_id. The issue is that the likes don't mention a hub at all, and the software ignores which hub they came from, and apply it to any post with the same post_id. Likes don't need an id, because you can't like a like. Meaning that you don't actually need to find one.

Comments are the same way, but since comments can be on multiple hubs (posts are only ever on your home hub), the comments are correctly placed under the appropriate hub/post_id

@P2P: The backend supports it cleanly. All the data is properly structured to make it a simple swap. I more or less migrated perfectly by hand. It's the ZeroMe frontend that causes the issues. Since it glitches with posts from multiple hubs (easy fix is to just check the hubs). And it also relies on the url to determine which hub your login/posts are in, which causes glitches (again, easy fix, just use the 'hub' variable in literally every hub data folder). That, and there's no 'migrate hub' button. Instead there's just a 'join hub', which deletes some data and such, and obviously that messes things up. It also doesn't switch the hub variable, or fix other things that could cause glitches.

After those two things are fixed (in the ZeroMe site itself), then it should work fine. A ZeroMe clone could certainly be used for clean migrations. Amusingly, the old zerome would still support the migrated account, due to how things work. But it'd still run into the same glitches as it is now (duplicate likes, login issues, following old profiles, etc.).

@P2P: Yea, I wrote out what happens. People's comments/likes are posted in the hub they're connected to. So if you 'migrate posts', the comments no longer properly link. A proper account migration would leave the comments there, and correctly distinguish between posts made on different hubs. If you're censored on a hub, you can only migrate *your* content (comments and posts). Not anyone else's.

>"IMO, comments (posted by others) and likes should be in the sub folder of the user, which makes the user can control all of the comments and likes,"

Comments and likes are posted on the appropriate hub that they refer to. I imagine that was by design, so that red hub users can see posts made on the red hub. Otherwise, you'd have to have every hub to see people's comments. Unless you meant comments posted by others going into your (OP) folder. Which is impossible, due to the way that ZeroNet authentication works. There's no way to touch another user's content. Period.

At best we keep it how it is, but correct the posts linkage issue (by relating comments/likes to same hub posts, and make a user's profile only ever link back to what's listed in the 'hub' entry).

>"All my comments posted to sub folder of an user in other hubs should be also backuped to my profile's hub and backup hubs in case of something unexpected happen."

I wasn't even aware this was a possibility. The only issue I can see here is that other people's comments would increase your folder size and more quickly reach your cap. But it *is* a good solution for migrating comments as well.
Should be working now.
@Adam The Victini: Once it's working smoothly, and not having login errors, I'll open it up.
On the bright side, my regular account seems to have been fixed.

Copy+pasting the fix for attention:

on line 4842 (in the 'checkuser' function) there's an SQL query. I changed it *from*

` "SELECT * FROM json WHERE cert_user_id = :cert_user_id AND user_name IS NOT NULL AND file_name = 'data.json'"`

and changed it *to*

`"SELECT * FROM json WHERE directory='data/users/"+this.site_info.auth_address+"' AND user_name IS NOT NULL AND file_name = 'data.json'"`

The issue was that it wasn't ever picking up my kaffieid account, because there was some cert_user_id problems. I changed it to instead point to the directory entry to determine user login. Since that's how it assumes it works anyway. Basing it on a mystical cert_user_id (essentially your cert username) is a bad idea, since it might not always be in the database (like mine wasn't).

KaffieID is just added to the drop down selector thing when you log in. You can easily switch between the two by clicking the 'yourname@zeroid.bit' in the top-right and then selecting which you want to use.
That happens because you migrated hubs. One hub has a 'post 3', and your new hub also has a 'post 3', so when you request post 3, both come up.
Looks like 14 characters.

@Gallium: Both? The people waiting around AFAIK don't know what I'm picking up though. So maybe not them. Though, I usually am the youngest person doing this kinda thing. At my doc, it's all old people. And the pharmacy usually has older people as well. CVS people didn't even bat an eye. Are they robots?

@Mcgoo: No, and at the moment, clicking 'join' on multiple hubs is buggy. ZeroMe expects your 'posts' (from data.json) to only be on one hub. When you 'join' a hub, it creates the default data in the hub you joined. There's also a 'hub' marker that points back to your home hub (the one you joined). And joining a hub makes that hub's marker point to itself, messing up some links.

Refer to my guide on how to manually (and properly) change hubs: http://127.0.0.1:43110/kaffie.bit/?Post:25:How+to+change+your+ZeroMe+Hub

@Mcgoo: Yea, to fix, just make your data.json in the kaffie hub folder (/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/data/users/15tCjXFHLNtBi9fb799hjd9VcUfTybimE4/data.json) the same as the ones from other hubs you're not a part of. That should fix everything. It'll also make this post disappear.

Edit: You might need to make the userdb site (1udb...blahblahblah) edited to have it point back to the right hub if it's changed.
@Klaus JÃ³nsson Zimmermann: Yea, that's always a nice surprise.
@Bobnoise: Not that I'm aware of, no. ZeroNet as a whole has an issue with large files.
Are you starting zeronet with `--debug`?

@Katyab: I actually have used music in the past. Sometimes it just backfires and I just make things worse :\. I'm feeling better now though, and hopefully with my meds instances like last night will be less of an occurance. Mr. Robot's definitely great though :D

Hmm... It looks like you either didn't follow my switching hubs guides completely/correctly. Or you you clicked 'join hub' when you weren't supposed to. So now you have two duplicate sets of data on infinity hub and kaffie hub.

To fix this, just take either one (whichever one you don't want to be on) and then remove these fields from your data.json:

"next_post_id": #,

"next_follow_id": #,

"avatar": "generate",

"intro": "description",

"post": [ {some posts} ]

"follow": [ {some follows} ]

And then change this field to match the hub you didn't remove/edit:

"hub": "hubaddress you want to stay on",

After that, just sign/publish, or make a comment/like on the hub you erased.

@ZAlex: Good to hear. I'll have to set it up on my opera browser and ensure the test works properly. It didn't pass because I obviously didn't have it set up :P.

@<tkarita/>: The port is ignored during the test. It literally tests the ability to navigate to sites using the zero://siteaddress and http://zero/siteaddress methods. So if you have it configured with 53110, you have to configure your browser to handle the zero:// and http://zero/ methods to go through 53110 instead. My 1-click install for the zero:// protocol only seems to work on firefox, and indeed defaults to the 43110 port.
@ZAlex: I just set my pac proxy to be system-wide (instead of just firefox). Both Safari and Opera are passing the http://zero/ test now.

@Shellbound: Unfortunately that doesn't help resolve glitches. It just fixes problems on your own end. The data is still mixed up until you sign/publish everything. The zero:// test involves loading an iframe with the url `zero://1A83ijw3boqTtqdLz8me7AqeK1nEK8yxeu/test.html?zp&prtl=[origin]` and ZeroNet forcefully moves the iframe content to the main page (by reloading). This leads to the success of the second test.

If the first one isn't working, it sounds like either the jquery isn't being ran, or it's not grabbing the file. Perhaps check the console and let me know if there's an error?

@<tkarita/>: Huh. Noscript blocks the iframe if it's pointing to a zero:// url. But if it's a http://zero/ iframe the test works as normal. I'm wondering if there's something wrong with the whitelist.

The protocol works by assigning 127.0.0.1:43110/kaffie.bit/?u=[address] as what to go to when you enter something in the zero://[address] protocol. So on everything but the initial type/click, it's being read as local host (rather than the protocol). So I'm completely baffled at why the test doesn't work.
@ZAlex: Ah, I wasn't capitalizing the first letter. And I kept trying to add '@zeroid.bit' as well.

Upon further thinking, the hardcoded format was likely an oversight by nofish in an attempt to keep usernames unique. Only give out certs with a unique name on the backend. And on the front end have verification that includes the name in the cert. It'd prevent people from just manually changing their ZeroID name as it'd fail to sign.

So perhaps just eliminating it is not the best way to go about things. I still personally think the format option is best. As some users may want to change their username but still retain access to their content. At the moment, this requires using a name-agnostic signer like Kaffiene, and then deleting the 'cert_sign' and 'cert_auth' fields in the content.json manually. This seems particularly non userfriendly for no real reason.

Umm... Yea, the cert_sign with the name is entirely useless, given I was able to do this: http://127.0.0.1:43110/talk.zeronetwork.bit/?Topic:11_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh

Why bother with cert_sign if we can just delete it and move on without it? I was able to spoof nofish@zeroid.bit on ZeroTalk. So clearly names are guaranteed not unique. All one has to do is change the name and delete cert_sign.

This is a huge flaw for anything that expects unique usernames. Seems like a waste of time to have something that limits user-ability when you can manually work around it.

@Talnicrom: Your zeronet isn't rejecting it, because I removed the cert_sign. See the code above. It just returns true if it's missing. It's definitely a bug. Either the cert_sign is needed, and the skip needs to be removed. Or it isn't and it shouldn't be there.

As for the 'useraddress#authtype/useraddress' that won't work. It explicitly has to be 'useraddress#authtype/name' otherwise zeronet will reject it. Technically I didn't have to include anything. I could've easily signed with just 'useraddress#authtype'. I simply added the singersite to make it distinguishably different from KaffieID clones.

I'm unsure of which way we should proceed. Forcing users to keep the same name to ensure the cert_sign is the same is dumb. It's not required at all (signs can be verified with just authaddress and authtype). I'm still entirely unsure of the purpose of including it. Why not just remove it from the content.json?

The files won't be accepted anyway if you don't have the user's private key. So ensuring that the authtype/authaddress/name is the same seems pointless.

@Talnicrom: Sorry, to clarify: The name itself is indeed useful for displaying a name of some sort. The original implementation was an attempt to keep this unique (hence ZeroID). Everything is signed according to auth_address and your private key.

Certificates have a few things to distinguish them: the site it's issued from, the user's public and private key. The type of authentication. The username, and the cert_sign. The cert_sign is reconstructed on each users' machine following the formula given. And then compared to the one included in content.json (which is a copy of the one that the site provides). However, there's no guarantee the site will use said formula, and thus the publish is rejected despite having the private key correct.

To bypass this, you remove the auth_type and cert_sign provided in the content.json. Now that these are lacking, the cert_sign check is skipped and it just verifies that the private key was used and signed the stuff correctly.

So the cert_sign is entirely unneeded. It can be removed manually, and doesn't help authenticate anything. So I'm wondering why bother having it? And if it remains, why not allow a formula config, so that non-unique name services can exist?

@P2P: Not that serious of a bug, tbh. AFAIK there's no way to abuse this to compromise security. It just bypasses the unique name thing. Users are still uniquely identifiable with their auth_address. If you hover over the nofish spoof, you'll see my auth_address, which has remained the same this entire time. So you can tell who the 'real' nofish is by that. It's just a serious bug for username uniqueness since it completely bypasses the backend stuff to guarantee unique names. I can't actually edit/change/be nofish with this :P.
@P2P: I've been spending the past while now trying to fix. I dun goof'd some stuff and the new update makes it difficult to change/fix. Hopefully everything should have returned to normal now.

@Sirenyc: Are you uploading them using the 'upload' page on the site? Or are you manually editing the data.json? If you're manually editing it, what I do is I drag the sidebar open, make sure I'm logged in, then copy and paste my id into the 'content.json' field so that it looks like this: data/userid/content.json. Then I sign, and it asks for the private key, at which point I enter my Id's private key. Should work.

I see your vids, so you're doing something right. Though, you might've hit the quota, as I almost have. Not sure if it'd give you a private key error for that though...

@Sirenyc: Should be in your data.json file: zeronetfolder/data/1FUQPLXHimgCvYHH7v3bJXspJ7bMBUXcEb/data/[youruserid]/data.json
